Wacky Wednesday's are awesome because it's a way to add a little extra fun into your day, with very little preparation. Here are some ways to incorporate wackiness into your day and please feel free to share some ideas below in the comments.

1. Switch out painting supplies: Use a toothbrush, stick with leaves at the end, or celery and green onions instead of a paintbrush to make a wacky painting.

2. Draw or color upside down: Tape paper to the underside of your table or desk and draw on the “ceiling.”

3. Walk backward. Mix it up and walk backward as you move around the house. Or you could walk sideways. Or ask your children for a wacky walking suggestion!

4. Have a picnic under the table. Put down a table cloth under the table and eat on the floor!

This week's FCMA Teacher Spotlight features: Ms. Mandy!

This summer, Ms. Mandy has been researching mythology, biking, gardening, and observing swallowtail caterpillars.

Last year was the first summer where she had monarch caterpillars and she had been nervous that they wouldn't have any monarchs this year. But she is excited to say that last week 2 monarch eggs hatched! Now there's 3 teensy tiny caterpillars and one more egg. She has been checking every day to try to find new eggs/caterpillars.

Ms. Mandy has also been lucky enough to have a young buck (with velvet antlers) visit a few times at night and in the morning as well as ending up having to learn a lot about her air conditioner when it stopped working!

Check out photos from Ms. Mandy's summer below including one where she took a hike at Kensington Metro.

A message from Ms. Mandy:
"I hope everyone is having a great summer full of discoveries!"

This month FCMA students are learning about the character trait perseverance.

We define perseverance as:
Keep trying even when it’s hard; Hard work; Use encouraging words and a positive attitude; Be patient with yourself

Some ideas on what you can do at home with your child involving the character trait perseverance is:

• Teaching your child to ride a bike or to play a sport
• Watch clips from a past Olympics and research their journey to the Olympics
• Help and encourage your child to work on their homework
• Ask your child to explain what perseverance is and why perseverance is an important trait
• Tell your child a story from your life that involved perseverance
• Read a story that relates to perseverance and discuss how the character showed perseverance.
• Watch videos like Finding Nemo that relate to perseverance and discuss how the film displayed perseverance.

Students are thrilled to have Mr. David as part of the FCMA family! They are looking forward to exploring new things in his class.
